original_data.Title: Introduction to Programming with MATLAB
original_data.Short Intro: This course teaches computer programming to those with little to no previous experience. It uses the programming system and language called MATLAB to do so because it is easy to learn, versatile and very useful for engineers and other professionals. MATLAB is a special-purpose language that is an excellent choice for writing moderate-size programs that solve problems involving the manipulation of numbers. The design of the language makes it possible to write a powerful program in a few lines. The problems may be relatively complex, while the MATLAB programs that solve them are relatively simple: relative, that is, to the equivalent program written in a general-purpose language, such as C++ or Java. As a result, MATLAB is being used in a wide variety of domains from the natural sciences, through all disciplines of engineering, to finance, and beyond, and it is heavily used in industry. Hence, a solid background in MATLAB is an indispensable skill in today’s job market.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Greek, Italian, Vietnamese, Korean, German, Russian, English, Spanish

unified_data.learning_outcomes: Learn computer programming using MATLAB, a versatile language for engineers and professionals. Master writing programs for numerical problem-solving in various fields like science, engineering, and finance, gaining an indispensable skill for the job market.
unified_data.price: Free to audit; paid certificate available

original_data.Title: Computational Neuroscience
original_data.Short Intro: This course provides an introduction to basic computational methods for understanding what nervous systems do and for determining how they function. We will explore the computational principles governing various aspects of vision, sensory-motor control, learning, and memory. Specific topics that will be covered include representation of information by spiking neurons, processing of information in neural networks, and algorithms for adaptation and learning. We will make use of Matlab/Octave/Python demonstrations and exercises to gain a deeper understanding of concepts and methods introduced in the course. The course is primarily aimed at third- or fourth-year undergraduates and beginning graduate students, as well as professionals and distance learners interested in learning how the brain processes information.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Italian, Vietnamese, German, Russian, English, Spanish
original_data.Skills: Computational Neuroscience,Artificial Neural Network,Reinforcement Learning,Biological Neuron Model,

We will explore the computational principles governing various aspects of vision, sensory-motor control, learning, and memory. Specific topics that will be covered include representation of information by spiking neurons, processing of information in neural networks, and algorithms for adaptation and learning. We will make use of Matlab/Octave/Python demonstrations and exercises to gain a deeper understanding of concepts and methods introduced in the course. The course is primarily aimed at third- or fourth-year undergraduates and beginning graduate students, as well as professionals and distance learners interested in learning how the brain processes information.
prerequisites: Introductory neuroscience is helpful but not required
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Upon completion, you'll grasp computational methods for understanding nervous system function, explore computational principles in vision, sensory-motor control, learning, memory, and learn about information representation by spiking neurons and neural networks.
unified_data.price: Variable (Coursera offers free audit, paid certificate)

original_data.Title: Robotics: Aerial Robotics
original_data.Short Intro: How can we create agile micro aerial vehicles that are able to operate autonomously in cluttered indoor and outdoor environments?  You will gain an introduction to the mechanics of flight and the design of quadrotor flying robots and will be able to develop dynamic models, derive controllers, and synthesize planners for operating in three dimensional environments.  You will be exposed to the challenges of using noisy sensors for localization and maneuvering in complex, three-dimensional environments.  Finally, you will gain insights through seeing real world examples of the possible applications and challenges for the rapidly-growing drone industry.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Italian, Vietnamese, German, Russian, English, Spanish

unified_data.title: Robotics: Aerial Robotics
unified_data.description: How can we create agile micro aerial vehicles that are able to operate autonomously in cluttered indoor and outdoor environments?  You will gain an introduction to the mechanics of flight and the design of quadrotor flying robots and will be able to develop dynamic models, derive controllers, and synthesize planners for operating in three dimensional environments.  You will be exposed to the challenges of using noisy sensors for localization and maneuvering in complex, three-dimensional environments.  Finally, you will gain insights through seeing real world examples of the possible applications and challenges for the rapidly-growing drone industry.
prerequisites: Familiarity with programming (e.g., Python or MATLAB) is helpful
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Students will learn mechanics of flight, quadrotor design, dynamic modeling, controller design, and path planning in 3D environments. They will also understand sensor challenges in localization and applications of drone technology.
unified_data.price: Coursera offers a subscription-based model for accessing courses and specializations. Price varies.

original_data.Title: Robotics: Computational Motion Planning
original_data.Short Intro: Robotic systems typically include three components: a mechanism which is capable of exerting forces and torques on the environment, a perception system for sensing the world and a decision and control system which modulates the robot's behavior to achieve the desired ends.  In this course we will consider the problem of how a robot decides what to do to achieve its goals. This problem is often referred to as Motion Planning and it has been formulated in various ways to model different situations.  You will learn some of the most common approaches to addressing this problem including graph-based methods, randomized planners and artificial potential fields.  Throughout the course, we will discuss the aspects of the problem that make planning challenging.
original_data.Skills: Motion Planning,Automated Planning And Scheduling,A* Search Algorithm,Matlab,

unified_data.title: Robotics: Computational Motion Planning

In this course we will consider the problem of how a robot decides what to do to achieve its goals. This problem is often referred to as Motion Planning and it has been formulated in various ways to model different situations.  You will learn some of the most common approaches to addressing this problem including graph-based methods, randomized planners and artificial potential fields.  Throughout the course, we will discuss the aspects of the problem that make planning challenging.
unified_data.prerequisites: Basic programming knowledge (e.g., Python or MATLAB), linear algebra, calculus, and introductory robotics concepts are recommended.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Understand motion planning problem formulations. Learn graph-based, randomized, and artificial potential field methods. Analyze challenges in robot planning and apply learned techniques to solve related problems.
unified_data.price: Coursera offers a free audit option. A certificate is available upon completion for a fee (Coursera Plus subscription or individual purchase).

original_data.Title: Numerical Methods for Engineers
original_data.Short Intro: This course covers the most important numerical methods that an engineer should know, including root finding, matrix algebra, integration and interpolation, ordinary and partial differential equations. We learn how to use MATLAB to solve numerical problems, and access to MATLAB online and the MATLAB grader is given to all students who enroll.

unified_data.title: Numerical Methods for Engineers
unified_data.description: This course covers the most important numerical methods that an engineer should know, including root finding, matrix algebra, integration and interpolation, ordinary and partial differential equations. We learn how to use MATLAB to solve numerical problems, and access to MATLAB online and the MATLAB grader is given to all students who enroll.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Apply numerical methods to solve engineering problems. Use MATLAB for root finding, matrix operations, integration, interpolation, and solving differential equations. Utilize the MATLAB grader for practice.

original_data.Title: Robotics: Mobility
original_data.Short Intro: How can robots use their motors and sensors to move around in an unstructured environment?  You will understand how to design robot bodies and behaviors that recruit limbs and more general appendages to apply physical forces that confer reliable mobility in a complex and dynamic world.  We develop an approach to composing simple dynamical abstractions that partially automate the generation of complicated sensorimotor programs.  Specific topics that will be covered include: mobility in animals and robots, kinematics and dynamics of legged machines, and design of dynamical behavior via energy landscapes.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: French, Portuguese (European), Russian, English, Spanish

unified_data.title: Robotics: Mobility
unified_data.description: How can robots use their motors and sensors to move around in an unstructured environment?  You will understand how to design robot bodies and behaviors that recruit limbs and more general appendages to apply physical forces that confer reliable mobility in a complex and dynamic world.  We develop an approach to composing simple dynamical abstractions that partially automate the generation of complicated sensorimotor programs.  Specific topics that will be covered include: mobility in animals and robots, kinematics and dynamics of legged machines, and design of dynamical behavior via energy landscapes.
unified_data.prerequisites: Calculus, linear algebra, basic physics, and introductory programming experience are recommended.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Design robot bodies and behaviors for mobility in unstructured environments. Understand kinematics and dynamics of legged machines. Design dynamical behaviors via energy landscapes using sensorimotor programs.
unified_data.price: Free to audit. Paid certificate available.

original_data.Title: Mathematics for Engineers: The Capstone Course
original_data.Short Intro: Mathematics for Engineers: The Capstone Course provides a capstone project for students who are completing the Mathematics for Engineers specialization. Students will first learn some basic concepts in computational fluid dynamics, and then apply these concepts to compute the fluid flow around a cylinder.   Access to MATLAB online and the MATLAB grader is given to all students who enroll.

unified_data.title: Mathematics for Engineers: The Capstone Course

Access to MATLAB online and the MATLAB grader is given to all students who enroll.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Learn basic concepts in computational fluid dynamics. Apply these concepts using MATLAB to compute fluid flow around a cylinder, completing a capstone project for the Mathematics for Engineers specialization.
unified_data.price: Free to audit, paid for certificate

original_data.Title: Modern Robotics, Course 6:  Capstone Project, Mobile Manipulation
original_data.Short Intro: The capstone project of the Modern Robotics specialization is on mobile manipulation: simultaneously controlling the motion of a wheeled mobile base and its robot arm to achieve a manipulation task.  This project integrates several topics from the specialization, including trajectory planning, odometry for mobile robots, and feedback control.  Beginning from the Modern Robotics software library provided to you (written in Python, Mathematica, and MATLAB), and software you have written for previous courses, you will develop software to plan and control the motion of a mobile manipulator to perform a pick and place task.  You will test your software on the KUKA youBot, a mobile manipulator consisting of an omnidirectional mecanum-wheel mobile base, a 5-joint robot arm, and a gripper.  The state-of-the-art, cross-platform V-REP robot simulator will be used to simulate the task.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: French, Portuguese (European), Russian, English, Spanish

unified_data.title: Modern Robotics, Course 6:  Capstone Project, Mobile Manipulation
unified_data.description: The capstone project of the Modern Robotics specialization is on mobile manipulation: simultaneously controlling the motion of a wheeled mobile base and its robot arm to achieve a manipulation task.  This project integrates several topics from the specialization, including trajectory planning, odometry for mobile robots, and feedback control.  Beginning from the Modern Robotics software library provided to you (written in Python, Mathematica, and MATLAB), and software you have written for previous courses, you will develop software to plan and control the motion of a mobile manipulator to perform a pick and place task.  You will test your software on the KUKA youBot, a mobile manipulator consisting of an omnidirectional mecanum-wheel mobile base, a 5-joint robot arm, and a gripper.  The state-of-the-art, cross-platform V-REP robot simulator will be used to simulate the task.
prerequisites: Completion of Modern Robotics Specialization Courses 1-5 or equivalent knowledge of robotics fundamentals, including kinematics, dynamics, control, and motion planning.
Proficiency in Python, Mathematica, or MATLAB.
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Develop software for motion planning and control of a mobile manipulator. Test the software on a simulated KUKA youBot to perform a pick and place task. Integrate trajectory planning, odometry, and feedback control concepts.
unified_data.price: Part of a paid specialization, individual course price may vary.

original_data.Title: Automating Image Processing
original_data.Short Intro: In this course, you will build on the skills acquired in Image Segmentation, Filtering, and Region Analysis to explore large sets of images and video files. It’s impractical to manually inspect results in large data sets. Automating image processing allows you to do your work more efficiently.

unified_data.title: Automating Image Processing
unified_data.description: In this course, you will build on the skills acquired in Image Segmentation, Filtering, and Region Analysis to explore large sets of images and video files. It’s impractical to manually inspect results in large data sets. Automating image processing allows you to do your work more efficiently.
unified_data.prerequisites: Image Segmentation, Filtering, Region Analysis, basic programming knowledge (e.g., MATLAB or Python)
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Efficiently process large image and video datasets through automation. Learn to inspect results and streamline workflows, leveraging acquired skills in image processing tasks.

original_data.Title: Robotics: Capstone
original_data.Short Intro: In our 6 week Robotics Capstone, we will give you a chance to implement a solution for a real world problem based on the content you learnt from the courses  in your robotics specialization. It  will also give you a chance to use mathematical and programming methods that researchers use in robotics labs.

unified_data.title: Robotics: Capstone
unified_data.description: In our 6 week Robotics Capstone, we will give you a chance to implement a solution for a real world problem based on the content you learnt from the courses  in your robotics specialization. It  will also give you a chance to use mathematical and programming methods that researchers use in robotics labs.
prerequisites: Completion of introductory courses in robotics or equivalent knowledge
Basic understanding of linear algebra and calculus
unified_data.learning_outcomes: Implement robotics solutions for real-world problems. Apply mathematical and programming methods used in robotics labs. Gain hands-on experience in robotics research and development using skills in Python, Raspberry Pi and MATLAB.

original_data.Title: Mastering Programming with MATLAB
original_data.Short Intro: The course builds on the foundation laid by the first course of the Specialization called “Introduction to Programming with MATLAB.” It covers more advanced programming concepts such as recursion, vectorization, function handles, algorithm efficiency and others. At the same time, it presents many features that make MATLAB a powerful programming environment for engineering and scientific computing, such as  its support for object oriented programming, the new user interface design environment and Live Scripts.
original_data.Subtitle Languages: Subtitles: Arabic, French, Portuguese (European), Italian, Vietnamese, German, Russian, English, Spanish

unified_data.title: Mastering Programming with MATLAB

At the same time, it presents many features that make MATLAB a powerful programming environment for engineering and scientific computing, such as  its support for object oriented programming, the new user interface design environment and Live Scripts.

original_data.Title: Introduction to Image Processing
original_data.Short Intro: In this introduction to image processing, you'll take your first steps in accessing and adjusting digital images for analysis and processing. You will load, save, and adjust image size and orientation while also understanding how digital images are recognized. You will then perform basic segmentation and quantitative analysis. Lastly, you will enhance the contrast of images to make objects of interest easier to identify.
